trans-unit.source: Create and Configure an Application Gateway with Internal Load Balancer (ILB) in a Virtual Network | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create and Configure an Application Gateway with Internal Load Balancer (ILB) in a Virtual Network | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This page provides instructions to configure an Azure Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balanced endpoint
trans-unit.target: This page provides instructions to configure an Azure Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balanced endpoint

trans-unit.source: Create an Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balancer (ILB)
trans-unit.target: Create an Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balancer (ILB)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Azure classic steps
trans-unit.target: Azure classic steps

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager Powershell steps
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager Powershell steps

trans-unit.source: Application Gateway can be configured with an internet facing VIP or with an internal end-point not exposed to the internet, also known as Internal Load Balancer (ILB) endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Application Gateway can be configured with an internet facing VIP or with an internal end-point not exposed to the internet, also known as Internal Load Balancer (ILB) endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Configuring the gateway with an ILB is useful for internal line of business applications not exposed to internet.
trans-unit.target: Configuring the gateway with an ILB is useful for internal line of business applications not exposed to internet.

trans-unit.source: It's also useful for services/tiers within a multi-tier application which sit in a security boundary not exposed to internet, but still require round robin load distribution, session stickiness, or SSL termination.
trans-unit.target: It's also useful for services/tiers within a multi-tier application which sit in a security boundary not exposed to internet, but still require round robin load distribution, session stickiness, or SSL termination.

trans-unit.source: This article will walk you through the steps to configure an application gateway with an ILB.
trans-unit.target: This article will walk you through the steps to configure an application gateway with an ILB.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin
trans-unit.target: Before you begin

trans-unit.source: Install latest version of the Azure PowerShell cmdlets using the Web Platform Installer.
trans-unit.target: Install latest version of the Azure PowerShell cmdlets using the Web Platform Installer.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the latest version from the **Windows PowerShell** section of the [Download page](http://azure.microsoft.com/downloads/).
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the latest version from the **Windows PowerShell** section of the [Download page](http://azure.microsoft.com/downloads/).

trans-unit.source: Verify that you have a working virtual network with valid subnet.
trans-unit.target: Verify that you have a working virtual network with valid subnet.

trans-unit.source: Verify that you have backend servers either in the virtual network, or with a public IP/VIP assigned.
trans-unit.target: Verify that you have backend servers either in the virtual network, or with a public IP/VIP assigned.

trans-unit.source: To create a new application gateway, perform the following steps in the order listed.
trans-unit.target: To create a new application gateway, perform the following steps in the order listed.

trans-unit.source: Create a new application gateway
trans-unit.target: Create a new application gateway

trans-unit.source: Configure the gateway
trans-unit.target: Configure the gateway

trans-unit.source: Set the gateway configuration
trans-unit.target: Set the gateway configuration

trans-unit.source: Start the gateway
trans-unit.target: Start the gateway

trans-unit.source: Verify the gateway
trans-unit.target: Verify the gateway

trans-unit.source: Create a new application gateway:
trans-unit.target: Create a new application gateway:

trans-unit.source: **To create the gateway**, use the `New-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.
trans-unit.target: **To create the gateway**, use the `New-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.

trans-unit.source: Note that billing for the gateway does not start at this point.
trans-unit.target: Note that billing for the gateway does not start at this point.

trans-unit.source: Billing begins in a later step, when the gateway is successfully started.
trans-unit.target: Billing begins in a later step, when the gateway is successfully started.

trans-unit.source: **To validate** that the gateway was created, you can use the `Get-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: **To validate** that the gateway was created, you can use the `Get-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In the sample, *Description*, *InstanceCount*, and *GatewaySize* are optional parameters.
trans-unit.target: In the sample, *Description*, *InstanceCount*, and *GatewaySize* are optional parameters.

trans-unit.source: The default value for *InstanceCount* is 2, with a maximum value of 10.
trans-unit.target: The default value for *InstanceCount* is 2, with a maximum value of 10.

trans-unit.source: The default value for *GatewaySize* is Medium.
trans-unit.target: The default value for *GatewaySize* is Medium.

trans-unit.source: Small and Large are other available values.
trans-unit.target: Small and Large are other available values.

trans-unit.source: *Vip* and *DnsName* are shown as blank because the gateway has not started yet.
trans-unit.target: *Vip* and *DnsName* are shown as blank because the gateway has not started yet.

trans-unit.source: These will be created once the gateway is in the running state.
trans-unit.target: These will be created once the gateway is in the running state.

trans-unit.source: Configure the gateway
trans-unit.target: Configure the gateway

trans-unit.source: An application gateway configuration consists of multiple values.
trans-unit.target: An application gateway configuration consists of multiple values.

trans-unit.source: The values can be tied together to construct the configuration.
trans-unit.target: The values can be tied together to construct the configuration.

trans-unit.source: The values are:
trans-unit.target: The values are:

trans-unit.source: **Backend server pool:** The list of IP addresses of the backend servers.
trans-unit.target: **Backend server pool:** The list of IP addresses of the backend servers.

trans-unit.source: The IP addresses listed should either belong to the VNet subnet, or should be a public IP/VIP.
trans-unit.target: The IP addresses listed should either belong to the VNet subnet, or should be a public IP/VIP.

trans-unit.source: **Backend server pool settings:** Every pool has settings like port, protocol, and cookie based affinity.
trans-unit.target: **Backend server pool settings:** Every pool has settings like port, protocol, and cookie based affinity.

trans-unit.source: These settings are tied to a pool and are applied to all servers within the pool.
trans-unit.target: These settings are tied to a pool and are applied to all servers within the pool.

trans-unit.source: **Frontend Port:** This port is the public port opened on the application gateway.
trans-unit.target: **Frontend Port:** This port is the public port opened on the application gateway.

trans-unit.source: Traffic hits this port, and then gets redirected to one of the backend servers.
trans-unit.target: Traffic hits this port, and then gets redirected to one of the backend servers.

trans-unit.source: **Listener:** The listener has a frontend port, a protocol (Http or Https, these are case-sensitive), and the SSL certificate name (if configuring SSL offload).
trans-unit.target: **Listener:** The listener has a frontend port, a protocol (Http or Https, these are case-sensitive), and the SSL certificate name (if configuring SSL offload).

trans-unit.source: **Rule:** The rule binds the listener and the backend server pool and defines which backend server pool the traffic should be directed to when it hits a particular listener.
trans-unit.target: **Rule:** The rule binds the listener and the backend server pool and defines which backend server pool the traffic should be directed to when it hits a particular listener.

trans-unit.source: Currently, only the *basic* rule is supported.
trans-unit.target: Currently, only the *basic* rule is supported.

trans-unit.source: The *basic* rule is round-robin load distribution.
trans-unit.target: The *basic* rule is round-robin load distribution.

trans-unit.source: You can construct your configuration either by creating a configuration object, or by using a configuration XML file.
trans-unit.target: You can construct your configuration either by creating a configuration object, or by using a configuration XML file.

trans-unit.source: To construct your configuration by using a configuration XML file, use the sample below.
trans-unit.target: To construct your configuration by using a configuration XML file, use the sample below.

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: The *FrontendIPConfigurations* element describes the ILB details relevant for configuring Application Gateway with an ILB.
trans-unit.target: The *FrontendIPConfigurations* element describes the ILB details relevant for configuring Application Gateway with an ILB.

trans-unit.source: The Frontend IP *Type* should be set to 'Private'
trans-unit.target: The Frontend IP *Type* should be set to 'Private'

trans-unit.source: The *StaticIPAddress* should be set to the desired internal IP on which the gateway will receive traffic.
trans-unit.target: The *StaticIPAddress* should be set to the desired internal IP on which the gateway will receive traffic.

trans-unit.source: Note that the *StaticIPAddress* element is optional.
trans-unit.target: Note that the *StaticIPAddress* element is optional.

trans-unit.source: If not set, an available internal IP from the deployed subnet is chosen.
trans-unit.target: If not set, an available internal IP from the deployed subnet is chosen.

trans-unit.source: The value of the *Name* element specified in *FrontendIPConfiguration* should be used in the HTTPListener's *FrontendIP* element to refer to the FrontendIPConfiguration.
trans-unit.target: The value of the *Name* element specified in *FrontendIPConfiguration* should be used in the HTTPListener's *FrontendIP* element to refer to the FrontendIPConfiguration.

trans-unit.source: Configuration XML sample
trans-unit.target: Configuration XML sample

trans-unit.source: Set the gateway configuration
trans-unit.target: Set the gateway configuration

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll set the application gateway.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll set the application gateway.

trans-unit.source: You can use the `Set-AzureApplicationGatewayConfig` cmdlet with a configuration object, or with a configuration XML file.
trans-unit.target: You can use the `Set-AzureApplicationGatewayConfig` cmdlet with a configuration object, or with a configuration XML file.

trans-unit.source: Start the gateway
trans-unit.target: Start the gateway

trans-unit.source: Once the gateway has been configured, use the `Start-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet to start the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Once the gateway has been configured, use the `Start-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet to start the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Billing for an application gateway begins after the gateway has been successfully started.
trans-unit.target: Billing for an application gateway begins after the gateway has been successfully started.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** The `Start-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet might take up to 15-20 minutes to complete.
trans-unit.target: **Note:** The `Start-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet might take up to 15-20 minutes to complete.

trans-unit.source: Verify the gateway status
trans-unit.target: Verify the gateway status

trans-unit.source: Use the `Get-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet to check the status of gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the `Get-AzureApplicationGateway` cmdlet to check the status of gateway.

trans-unit.source: If *Start-AzureApplicationGateway* succeeded in the previous step, the State should be *Running*, and the Vip and DnsName should have valid entries.
trans-unit.target: If *Start-AzureApplicationGateway* succeeded in the previous step, the State should be *Running*, and the Vip and DnsName should have valid entries.

trans-unit.source: This sample shows the cmdlet on the first line, followed by the output.
trans-unit.target: This sample shows the cmdlet on the first line, followed by the output.

trans-unit.source: In this sample, the gatway is running, and is ready to take traffic.
trans-unit.target: In this sample, the gatway is running, and is ready to take traffic.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** The application gateway is configured to accept traffic at the configured ILB endpoint of 10.0.0.10 in this example.
trans-unit.target: **Note:** The application gateway is configured to accept traffic at the configured ILB endpoint of 10.0.0.10 in this example.

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.target: If you want more information about load balancing options in general, see:

trans-unit.source: Azure Load Balancer
trans-unit.target: Azure Load Balancer

trans-unit.source: Azure Traffic Manager
trans-unit.target: Azure Traffic Manager

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
